skill.name: seaborn
skill.description: Statistical visualization with pandas integration. Use for quick exploration of distributions, relationships, and categorical comparisons with attractive defaults. Best for box plots, violin plots, pair plots, heatmaps. Built on matplotlib. For interactive plots use plotly; for publication styling use scientific-visualization.
skill.summary: Create publication-quality statistical graphics for data analysis with seaborn visualization library
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: All 1063 static findings are false positives. The scanner misinterpreted markdown documentation syntax as security issues. Backticks in markdown are code formatting, not shell commands. YAML frontmatter delimiters were flagged as crypto algorithms. Code examples in documentation were flagged as system reconnaissance. No executable code or security risks present.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: The scanner detected markdown backticks used for inline code formatting (`x='value'`) and code blocks (```python). These are documentation syntax, not actual shell commands. No command execution occurs in this documentation-only skill. Evidence: SKILL.md lines 27-38, 61-70, 89-100 show code examples in markdown code blocks with no actual execution.

The scanner flagged YAML frontmatter delimiters (---) as weak crypto. The --- at file start/end is standard YAML metadata syntax, not cryptographic code. Evidence: SKILL.md line 1 and 7, references/examples.md line 1-3 show standard YAML frontmatter with no cryptographic algorithms.

The scanner flagged file I/O patterns in documentation code examples (like pd.read_csv, plt.savefig). These are legitimate data visualization patterns, not reconnaissance. Evidence: references/examples.md lines 15-20 show standard pandas file loading for data analysis workflows.

The scanner flagged network-related code examples in documentation. These are legitimate visualization patterns, not reconnaissance. Evidence: SKILL.md line 195 shows simple lineplot code with no network activity.

content.value_statement: This skill helps you create publication-quality statistical graphics for data analysis. Use it for exploratory data analysis, distribution comparisons, correlation heatmaps, and multi-panel figures with minimal code.
actual_capabilities: Create scatter plots, line plots, and relational visualizations
Build distribution plots including histograms, KDE, and violin plots
Generate categorical comparison plots with box plots and bar charts
Create correlation heatmaps and clustered matrix visualizations
Build multi-panel figures with faceted grids
Apply publication-ready themes and color palettes
limitations: Cannot create interactive plots (use plotly for interactivity)
Cannot generate 3D visualizations (use matplotlib or plotly)
Requires pandas DataFrame input format for best results
No direct support for geographic maps (use geopandas)

use_cases.title: Explore datasets visually
use_cases.description: Quickly generate pairwise plots, distributions, and correlations for exploratory data analysis workflows

use_cases.title: Create publication figures
use_cases.description: Generate statistical graphics with confidence intervals, error bars, and professional styling for research papers

use_cases.title: Visualize model outputs
use_cases.description: Display feature distributions, pairwise relationships, and categorical comparisons for model validation

prompt_templates.title: Basic scatter plot
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a scatter plot showing the relationship between total_bill and tip from a tips dataset, colored by day

prompt_templates.title: Distribution comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Show the distribution of values across different categories using violin plots with jittered points

prompt_templates.title: Correlation heatmap
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a correlation heatmap with annotations for numerical columns in my dataset

prompt_templates.title: Multi-panel dashboard
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a faceted visualization with multiple subplots comparing groups across different variables

output_examples.input: Create a box plot comparing values across categories with individual data points overlaid
output: Box plot showing quartile distributions with individual points for each category
Points are jittered to prevent overlap
Categories are ordered by median value
Colors distinguish different groups within each category

best_practices: Use long-form DataFrame data for maximum compatibility with all seaborn functions
Choose figure-level functions (relplot, displot, catplot) when faceting is needed
Apply semantic mappings (hue, size, style) to encode multiple variables visually
anti_patterns: Using unnamed arrays instead of DataFrames (loses axis labels)
Manually creating subplots when figure-level functions with col/row would suffice
Overplotting without using appropriate jitter or transparency settings

faq.question: What is seaborn best used for?
faq.answer: Seaborn excels at statistical visualization including distributions, relationships, and categorical comparisons with automatic aggregation.

faq.question: How does seaborn differ from matplotlib?
faq.answer: Seaborn provides higher-level functions with statistical defaults and prettier aesthetics while remaining fully compatible with matplotlib.

faq.question: Can I create interactive plots with seaborn?
faq.answer: No, seaborn creates static plots. Use plotly or bokeh for interactive visualizations.

faq.question: What data format does seaborn require?
faq.answer: Seaborn works best with pandas DataFrames in long format where each column is a variable and each row is an observation.

faq.question: How do I save publication-quality figures?
faq.answer: Use fig.savefig('filename.pdf', dpi=300) or .png for high-resolution output suitable for journals.

faq.question: Does seaborn support 3D plotting?
faq.answer: No, seaborn is 2D only. Use matplotlib's mplot3d or plotly for 3D visualizations.
